The fire is moving at 50 metres a minute.</p><p>The nearby village of Nemaska, home to about 500 Cree, has been evacuated. An offshoot of the Nemiscau fire did come within 800 metres of the village Friday but had retreated to a distance of 2 kilometres by yesterday evening.</p><p>The smoke is so dense, the provincial forest fire protection service cannot fly its planes through the region.</p><p>With visibility in Toronto cut to 3 kilometres yesterday, many called Environment Canada to find out why.</p><p>"I had someone call me to say it (the smell) was a welcome relief from the garbage," said Boisvert, referring to the city strike now in its second week that has piled up garbage all over.</p><p>Chantal Drapeau of Quebec's forest fire protection service, said with winds from the west today, the Gaspe Peninsula and Quebec's North Shore will see and smell the smoke next.</p><p>The situation is considered critical, with no rain likely before Tuesday.</p><p>There are many fires north of Lac-Saint-Jean that are out of control, "about 11 in all," Drapeau said. "The forecast is calling for nice weather through Tuesday, maybe even Wednesday, and ...stronger winds as of Sunday (today). So none of this helps us."</p><p>Wind shifts overnight were expected to clear skies over much of Ontario by this morning.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata It's born out of experience and practice, and we've tested it," Gledhill said Friday.</p><p>The Tasmanian strategy for surviving a forest fire is to: create a defensible space around your home by removing forest fuels and flammable material; use fire-resistant building materials; and prepare to fight with tools and water.</p><p>Years of fire research in Australia suggest that 90 per cent of property damage is not caused by a wall of flames entering a subdivision, but from the ember showers the fire throws ahead of itself, Gledhill said.</p><p>During last summer's forest fire in Kelowna, a handful of residents refused to evacuate when the Aug. 22 firestorm razed more than 200 houses.</p><p>B.C. Forest Service officials point to the differences in foliage, forest types and flat terrain in Tasmania as a key reason for the diverging firefighting strategies. Fifty-thousand British Columbians were ordered out of their homes last summer, and not one was injured or killed.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5CRT-1P41-JBVR-32FD-00000-00Keeping power on in Yellowknife proves difficult during season's many wildfires2014-07-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisWEATHER,NATIONALKeeping power on in Yellowknife proves difficult during season's many wildfiresFires keep knocking out power in YellowknifeThe Canadian Press

YELLOWKNIFE - Keeping Yellowknife's electricity on is proving to be a challenge during what Northwest Territories Power Corp. calls one of the worst years for wildfires in 30 years.

Company spokeswoman Pam Coulter says a new forest fire knocked out the city's main supply line from its Snare hydro facility on Wednesday.

The utility was able to switch to backup power from diesel generators at Jackfish Lake near Yellowknife, but Coulter says those have only been able to supply limited electricity due to recent lightning damage.

She says the Snare line was reactivated after only a couple of hours, but she says the company is still asking people to conserve power.

Coulter says the line wasn't damaged by the fire - she explains smoke and gasses produced by the fire can cause the line to ground and trip.

The community of Bechoko (BEH-cho-ko), northwest of Yellowknife, continues to operate on backup generators after a fire earlier this week knocked out a branch of the hydro line from the Snare facility.

That fire also caused power interruptions in Yellowknife. Coulter says crews can't get to the line because there's so much smoke.

The Snare hydroelectric dams are located approximately 145 kilometres northwest of Yellowknife.

Smoke from some of the fires continues to force Highway 3, the main route to Yellowknife, to close periodically.

"It is the rays of light passing through the (dust) particles."</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Canadian Press</p></bodyText></section><p>The fine dust particles in the smoke left a film on cars throughout Montreal. The city's public health authority issued a warning to senior citizens, children and people with respiratory problems to remain inside. They also recommended people refrain from physically exerting activities.</p><p>Quebec's forest fire protection service said the smoke is coming from a fire that has been burning since July 2 in the region of Nemiscau, near James Bay. That fire prompted the evacuation of 500 aboriginal people from the village of Nemaska on Friday.</p><p>Another 130 aboriginals were evacuated from the village of Chisabisi on Sunday afternoon and taken to the administrative centre of Rouyn-Noranda, about 650 kilometres northwest of Montreal.</p><p>Although the Nemiscau fire is the most noticeable of 43 fires burning in northern Quebec, it is not the most severe.</p><p>A fire north of Lac St-Jean -- between the Manicouagan Reservoir and Mistassini River -- has burned about 650 square kilometres of forest and is currently considered out of control, one of 10 fires in the area with such a designation.</p><p>"Those are fires we basically have to leave alone for the meantime," said Eric Santerre of the provincial forest fire protection service, noting the smoke is too thick for planes to travel through it.</p><p>"We need rain to bring down the amount of smoke before we can go in."</p><p>Santerre said there is no rain forecast for the area until at least Thursday, "so it won't be easy."</p><p>Only 15 square kilometres of Quebec forest has been claimed by forest fires at the beginning of July, but that number is now at 1,083 square kilometres, Santerre said.</p><p>The average for this time of year is about 270 square kilometres of forest burned.</p><p>There are 500 firefighters working to put out the fires.</p><p>A fire ban has been in effect since July 4 in practically every region of Quebec north of the St. Lawrence River.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5NG7-FGX1-JBVR-30VG-00000-00Alberta introduces legislation to set standards, license homebuilders2017-05-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisBUSINESS,PRAIRIES/BCAlberta introduces legislation to set standards, license homebuildersAlberta set to license homebuildersDean BennettThe Canadian Press

EDMONTON - Alberta is proposing legislation that would require builders of new homes be licensed so as to curb fly-by-night operators, end shoddy work and help consumers make choices.

"When Albertans buy a new home, they're making one of the biggest investments they'll ever make," Municipal Affairs Minister Shaye Anderson said Thursday.

"We want to make sure that Albertans are protected."

If the bill passes, builders will need to be licensed by the province to construct new homes and condos, or to undertake renovations involving more than 75 per cent of a home's floor space.

The licence would set minimum standards and ensure builders were held accountable for their work.

The proposed law doesn't apply to those building their own homes.

Ryan Scott, president of the Canadian Home Builders' Association, said while many homebuilders are professional and responsible, "the ability to remove builders who demonstrate a proven, negative track record will be a benefit to every Albertan."

Protections would be in place during a phase-in period so that consumers having a house constructed by a builder who failed to qualify for a licence weren't left in the lurch. In such cases, there would be provisional licences granted to the builder, subject to conditions, for the project's completion.

The bill calls for department officials to rule on licence applications, focusing on a builder's work record, finances and corporate structure. They would also take into account the possibility of vexatious complaints.

Licences, once granted, could also be revoked.

A builder could appeal a licence rejection to an arm's-length panel.

Ontario, Quebec, and British Columbia already have similar licensing programs in place.

The cost for a licence would be $600 with an annual renewal fee of $500, matching fees in British Columbia. Ontario and Quebec charge more.

There are an estimated 4,000 residential builders in Alberta. As it stands, there are no requirements placed on them and there is no legal way to stop them from operating, even if they commit fraud or breach labour laws.

The changes build on the current New Home Buyer Protection Act, which requires new homes to be backed by a warranty. But that recourse only kicks in after problems have arisen.

The province also plans to create an online registry to help consumers pick a builder.

The bill was shaped in part by the rebuild of Fort McMurray, which lost entire neighbourhoods to a forest fire a year ago. Builders there have had to complete a declaration before applying for a building permit.

Erected for Summerfelt's aunt and uncle, it was in a wilderness area of Arizona -- so close to dense forest that holes were cut into the outside deck so trees could poke through. The house was about 20 kilometres from the nearest town, on a steep slope and exposed to potentially high winds.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>SOUTHAMSTAR NETWORK</p></bodyText></section><p>All of these factors, when added to Arizona's dry climate, put the house at high risk when a lightning-sparked forest fire raged through the region in 1990. The flames came within 400 metres of the structure.</p><p>The wind finally shifted and the house survived. But the owners of another Summerfelt-built house weren't so lucky.</p><p>Hard to reach</p><p>Their home in Santa Barbara, Calif., was also nestled among trees, and on a similarly steep slope that invited high winds while making it difficult for emergency workers to approach. It was destroyed in a mid-1989 forest fire.</p><p>Since then, Summerfelt's Arizona relatives have replaced their cedar roof with something far more fire-resistant.</p><p>The owners of both homes are part of a trend in which urbanites are abandoning big-city lights in search of a haven in the country. But if that haven is in semi-wilderness, it could be consumed by a forest fire.</p><p>Summerfelt was in Kananaskis, Alta, recently for an international fire-fighting conference during which much of the discussion was about "interface fires," or blazes in areas where human development is invading wilderness.</p><p>The tragic interface fire was a 1983 inferno in Australia that killed 76 people and destroyed more than 2,500 homes. That so-called Ash Wednesday fire shocked Donald Macarthur's countrymen into adopting preventive measures, the Australian firefighting expert told the conference.</p><p>As a result, many communities Down Under now legislate buffer zones between houses and trees, emergency water supplies, access roads and building materials. But Macarthur said there are still some Australians who oppose the land-use and building restrictions as an unwarranted intrusion.</p><p>"One of the biggest problems we face is getting people to believe it could happen to them," agreed Jim Law, spokesman for Kananaskis Country recreation area.</p><p>K-Country is among several western Canadian groups that organized the Partners in Protection conference to help Canadians guard themselves and their rural property against forest fires.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata INDEX: Environment, Health, Forestry; HL:Rainy weather helps firefighters corral Alberta's biggest forest fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>EDMONTON</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>EDMONTON (CP) - Firefighters, aided by a rainy, cool weekend, have finally corralled Alberta's largest forest.</p><p nitf:lede="true">After weeks of raging out of control, a massive fire near Chisholm, about 150 kilometres north of Edmonton, was listed Monday as being held.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- That means the fire has been contained and is unlikely to grow, said Pat Loewen, fire information officer for Alberta Sustainable Resources.</p><p>The blaze has charred 1,160 square kilometres of land, nearly twice the size of Toronto.</p><p>Government meteorologist Nick Nimchuck said up to 50 millimetres of rain fell on the fire in the last week, including a steady drizzle over the weekend.</p><p>Timber, leaves and branches are now moistened so it's tougher to burn.</p><p>"A bit every day for several days in a row is a very effective way of wetting the fuels instead of getting one large amount all at one time,'' Nimchuk said.</p><p>Loewen said the fire was smouldering and creating a lot of smoke on Monday.</p><p>Firefighters with portable water pumps were dousing hot spots.</p><p>"They'll be digging that particular area up, just like with your campfire,'' Loewen said.</p><p>"What we'd like you to do with your camp fires is to make sure you can put your hand in the ashes before you go. Pour water on it, stir it up, and pour water on it again. That's what they will be doing.''</p><p>However, Loewen said the war is far from over with the Chisholm fire.</p><p>"We have a lot of work to do. We're hoping Mother Nature stays on our side. If we jump back immediately into hot, dry windy weather, we stand the risk of having some difficulties with it again,'' he said.</p><p>Residents of nearby Smith and Hondo remained Monday on evacuation alert.</p><p>To date, there have been 401 fires in Alberta that have destroyed 1,500 square kilometres of land. Battling the fires have cost Alberta taxpayers $36 million.</p><p>The Chisholm fire alone has cost $10 million.</p><p>No fires were listed out of control on Monday.</p><p>There were 514 firefighters working on the Chisholm fire on Monday, along with 34 helicopters, 31 dozers, 35 water trucks and 20 skidders.</p><p>The forecast for the next few days was for cool temperatures, low winds and a chance of showers over the fire area.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5SS3-7501-JDH3-G4PK-00000-00Op-Ed: Province must choose education over pricey Vic High upgrade2018-07-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisOPINIONOp-Ed: Province must choose education over pricey Vic High upgrade

By Stan Bartlett

With looming elections, Greater Victoria School Board trustees have voted to preserve Vic High for its heritage and amenities, rather than investing in a more affordable, state-of the art facility built to a high environmental standard.

We are shocked that trustees dismissed the $68-million, state-of-the-art LEED option to house 1,000 students. Instead, trustees recommended the so-called 'seismic upgrade plus enhancements option' at a cost of $73.3 million. Both options include a $6 million neighbourhood learning centre.

How valid is this third set of estimates? Whatever the cost, the end result will be a facility of inferior quality and lower environmental standards, at an additional capital cost of more than $5.3 million. Of note, operating and maintenance costs for this fixer-upper will be more well into the future.

We urge the province to reject outright the trustees' recommendation.

While the City of Victoria put Vic High on its heritage registry, it never formally protected the property. There's no heritage covenant on the property and it's neither a provincial or national historic site. The National Trust for Canada put Vic High on its so-called 'Top 10 Endangered Places List' designation far too late in the process to have much sway or credibility with taxpayers.

Construction upgrades are guesstimates. The reserves and inflation allowance using ministry figures has been adjusted upward to $13 million for a new build to allow for escalating construction costs. By comparison, the reserves and inflation allowance is $17 million for the so-called 'seismic upgrading plus option.'

The bottom line? There's more risk to the taxpayer, since estimating the costs of an upgrade for an old facility is notoriously difficult.

On top of that, ongoing maintenance and operating costs will be more in a facility completely not built to very high LEED environmental standards. Taxpayers will pay more for such things as heating, ventilation and maintenance during the facility's shorter life cycle.

Upgrades are just the beginning. Don't be seduced by the $73.3 million estimate, since local taxpayers might be on the hook for upgrades not considered seismic-related. Understandably, the school board is worried provincial funding will not include high efficiency windows, repointing the masonry, repairing or replacing failing terracotta, dealing with interior heritage issues, and adding various energy efficiency measures.

So, if the upgrade option proceeds, the budget for these essential improvements might add to the tax burden of local taxpayers.

Vic High is more than bricks and mortar. As expected, students, parents and alumni support preserving the old structure – no matter the cost. The school's proud history, however, can be carried on in a wonderful new school and even enhanced by students and the community.

We urge the province to consider a compromise, a Fourth Option that advocates a new school incorporating elements of the old school such as large windows and ornate facades.

Demands on education dollars are escalating, beyond the requirements of a new teachers' contract, the replacement of portables and the Supreme Court decision on classroom size. Serious external financial pressures, such as another costly forest fire season or a trade war are ever present.

Finally, we urge Education Minister Rob Fleming to consider the five-year capital plan just submitted to his ministry: It outlines the need for more than $67 million in seismic upgrades in 10 other SD61 schools. Those numbers are about to "grow significantly" because of new seismic standards and testing.

In addition, $28.7 million is needed for other capital needs including a downtown Victoria elementary school.

Prudent funding of a new Vic High will send a message to voters that the province knows the basics of math when it comes to spending public dollars. Frugality and common sense must rule the day.

Stan Bartlett is chair Of Grumpy Taxpayer$ of Greater Victoria.

Interior stands trial</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KAMLOOPS, B.C. (CP) _ The man accused of starting the disastrous Barriere wildfire in 2003 says he stomped out a cigarette on his property just moments before a fire started.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The information was read out in provincial court Wednesday in an agreed statement of facts at the start of Mike Barre's trial.</p><p nitf:lede="true">He is charged with dropping a burning substance within one kilometre of a forest on July 30, 2003, a contravention of B.C.'s Forest Practices Code.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Court heard Barre was scouting out places to set up a satellite dish on his rural property in the B.C. Interior.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>He said he threw away a lit cigarette, ground it out and moments later saw smoke billowing from the grass.</p><p>Barre called 911. He said no more than five minutes later the fire was out of control.</p><p>The fire pushed thousands of people from their homes and destroyed 75 houses and buildings along with 26,000 hectares of forest.</p><p>Electronic technician Joe Birkeland, who was helping locate a spot for Barre's satellite dish, said he saw Barre smoking on the hill where the fire started.</p><p>Birkeland testified that when smoke appeared he overheard Barre say: "I though I put it out deep enough.''</p><p>Forty-five minutes later, the hillside was blazing, with teams of firefighters backed by aircraft working to put it out.</p><p>Two days later, the fire pushed past Barriere and Louis Creek, displacing thousands from their homes.</p><p>Stephen Grimaldi, a senior forestry protection officer, told Judge William Sundhu he arrived in McLure several days after the blaze started to begin his investigation.</p><p>He said he set out to determine the wildfire's origin by eliminating possible causes until the most likely remained.</p><p>The fire's path up the hillside made impossible any suggestion that the fire was started by nearby rail or highway traffic, or other industrial activity, he said.</p><p>"You eliminated lightning strikes as well?'' asked prosecutor Jonathan Oliphant.</p><p>"Yes,'' Grimaldi replied, adding a lightning detection system in place in B.C. showed there had been no strikes in the area for at least five days.</p><p>Grimaldi identified the fire's ignition point based on Barre's statements, the court was told.</p><p>He even walked Grimaldi to the place where he believed he dropped the cigarette.</p><p>Grimaldi told the court he measured the depth of the ground fuel _ the dead needles, twigs, stick, dead grass and vegetation _ on the forested hillside behind Barre's house.</p><p>"There was a fair amount of fuel,'' said Grimaldi, noting the duff layer was nine centimetres deep.</p><p>The officer suggested a cigarette stubbed with a toe in such conditions would not have been extinguished, unless it was pushed all the way through the flammable material to the dirt beneath.</p><p>"Did you find any other evidence of the potential cause of the fire beside the cigarette?'' asked Oliphant.</p><p>"No,'' answered the officer.</p><p>Barre has pleaded not guilty.</p><p>If a person is found guilty, the provincial statute allows for fines of up to $1 million and three years in prison, but maximum penalties are almost never imposed. The act does not specify minimum penalties.</p><p>Some businesses destroyed by the fire say they intend to launch a lawsuit against Barre.</p><p>But more than 500 Barriere-area residents signed a petition in March calling on the Crown to stay the charge against Barre.</p><p>One of the organizers of the petition said it was designed to show support for the man many believe did all he could in the circumstances to stop the fire from spreading.</p><p>Its expected defence lawyer John Hogg will ask the judge to visit McLure, to see for himself the nature of the hillside, the trail and the soils behind Barre's house.</p><p>Hogg told the judge he intends to make that request at some point because pictures taken by witnesses and investigators don't do the scene justice.</p><p>"One of the issues will be what the ground is like there _ is it soft or hard, is it barren, or is it sandy,'' said Hogg.</p><p>(Canadian Press, Kamloops Daily News)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5P78-Y3T1-JDH3-G453-00000-00Picnickers, boaters, campers crowd Golden Ears2017-08-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisNEWSPicnickers, boaters, campers crowd Golden EarsPhil Melnychuk

People keep packing in, making this fire-infested year one of the busiest ever for Golden Ears Provincial Park.

According to Stu Burgess, with Alouette Park Management, on B.C. Day, a total of 3,050 cars, trucks, SUVs and motorcycles filed through the park gates.

On average, each vehicle contained 3.5 people.

Add the campers and the day-users together and that's more than 10,000 people that day clamoring for campsites, jockeying for parking stalls and picking the best place to picnic.

That's not the busiest day, however, so far this year. On the May long weekend, 3,207 vehicles came into the park in one day.

"That's the most I've seen here in 23 years," Burgess said.

That sunny day was turning point for a long, hot summer following a cold, snowy winter.

Park closures in the Interior, due to wildfires, mean more people are looking to the Lower Mainland for recreation.

For all of last July, Golden Ears , one of the province's busiest parks, drew 55,000 day-use vehicles.

"That's 2,000 more than we've had before."

Long weekends usually see the operators close the front gates of the park, when the day-use area is at capacity.

That allows some time for people to find places to park and for others to leave and to create some more space, after which the gates are re-opened. This weekend though, they only had to close the gates for half an hour on Sunday. "Just so we didn't get into the situation where there were too many people trying to get too few parking spots."

All of the reserved and first-come, first-served campsites were taken, requiring people who lined up in the early mornings to turn back.

According to the most recent figures , 596,000 people visited the day-use area in Golden Ears in 2013/14, an increase of four per cent from the year before.

However, the number of campers dropped by about the same percent, to 107,00 in that period. Overall, park use has jumped 13 per cent in 2013/14 compared to the average of the preceding three years.

Burgess said the park has expanded its facilities only once in the last 40 years, adding 55 campsites at North Beach.

The park wasn't on the list for expansion when the government, in March, announced the first phase of campsite expansion in the province with new 350 new campsites.

Golden Ears currently has 400 campsites, 300 of which are reservation only.

The forest fire danger rating in the park is currently at extreme, meaning campfires are banned while propane stoves and propane-powered fire pits are allowed, as well as briquett barbecues and white gas Coleman stoves.

urn:contentItem:5P5K-5PJ1-JDH3-G48B-00000-00Fire risk worries North Saanich residents in Dean Park Estates2017-08-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisNEWSFire risk worries North Saanich residents in Dean Park Estates

Tim Collins/News staff

As a smokey haze obscures the sky and casts a otherworldly orange tinge across the sky, some residents of Dean Park Estates have expressed concern about the potential of a wildfire taking hold in the 174 acres of the adjacent John Dean Provincial Park.

"It's really a bad situation right now. The storms this winter knocked down a lot of trees and branches and all that debris is now sitting on the ground, drying out. All it's going to take is one spark, and the whole thing could go up," said Dean Park Estates resident Pam McCorquodale.

The concern of a wildfire in the park is especially concerning for the residents of the approximately 780 homes in Dean Park Estates.

"I live right on the edge of the park and I'm really scared that, if a fire breaks out, my home is going to go. It's like living next to a ticking time bomb and I wish there was something being done to remove and dispose of the fire fuel on the ground throughout the park," said Virgina Rouslin another Dean Park Estate resident.

"I've seen down in Oregon where they have done that to prevent wild fires and I don't understand why we don't do it here."

The access road to the park was closed last week due to the extreme fire risk, but the trails throughout the park remain open. And although no fires are permitted within park boundaries and no smoking is allowed, area residents have reported that cigarette butts can regularly be seen, discarded along the trails.

"All it takes is one idiot to throw a cigarette butt into the woods and we'd have a fire, so it's really everyone's responsibility to use extreme caution when using the park," said John Trelford, North Saanich Fire Chief.

He advocates that area residents also take reasonable precautions to safeguard their surrounding property. According to government websites, those actions include removing combustible materials, including dead plants, leaves, weeds, patio furniture, firewood, and other decorative items from within ten metres of your home. Gates should be secured in an open position and propane tanks should be moved away from the house.

Another issue raised by some community residents involves the fact that Mount Newton, within the park's boundaries, is home to a significant amount of communications equipment that, in part, is used to control air and marine traffic throughout the region. A fire in the park could destroy that equipment and disrupt that communication and control.

Should a fire break out, it would fall under the auspices of the B.C. Wildfire Service as the North Saanich Fire Department is not equipped to deal with a forest fire. According to Trelford, his department would respond to the area to help safeguard the homes adjacent to the park.

urn:contentItem:5P5K-5PJ1-JDH3-G4DV-00000-00Business spotlight: Longtime jeweller opts for retirement2017-08-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisBUSINESSBusiness spotlight: Longtime jeweller opts for retirement

On August 26, D C Quinn's Jewellers is closing its doors after 30 years of business.

"I'm retiring," says goldsmith Dennis Quinn as he quips a little rhyme about being 'bent and busted.'

Over the years the business has been in various locations around town.

"We started off in a small little store on Shuswap Street and we've evolved from there to here with a full blown gift shop," says Lynne. There other locations included Alexander Street (where Victorian Lace is now) and across the street from their present location, where they have been for six years. Over the past decades, they have seen a few changes in jewelry styles.

"Thirty years ago it was either yellow gold or silver, there was no white gold. Over the years that has changed and now white gold is more predominate. It's gone from traditional settings to more designer stuff," says Lynne.

Because they have been in business this long, most of their customers have become their friends as well.

Dennis is booked solid until his final day, so he isn't taking any more repairs, and he is adamant he isn't doing any more work once he's retired. Dennis and Lynne plan to spend their retirement fishing and golfing.

"Well, me not so much," says Lynne, "I'll be the tagalong."

Up for Sale

Business partners Marty Bootsma and Warren Welter have their car wash for sale. They own the Petro Car Wash formerly known as Lakeshore Car Wash.

Over the past several months they have put in improvements and it's been very successful.

"It's a great small business, we're enjoying it" says Marty, "but we're looking to sell. We both have personal circumstances that have changed."

Ecotreats

They haven't posted an opening date but on their Facebook page Ecotreats says they're opening soon. They will be located in the former Java Jive location at the corner of the Trans Canada and Alexander Street.

Customers can expect great organic coffee, organic baking, smoothies, paninis, breakfast burritos, and gluten free and vegan options.

They also have a location in Scotch Creek.

Tourism stats

Shuswap tourism numbers for July are down somewhat (around seven per cent drop from 2016), says Salmon Arm Chamber Manager Corryn Grayston.

"I suspect it is totally attributable to the fires and air quality issues throughout the province. However, Shuswap Tourism, Thompson Okanagan Tourism Association and ourselves are making concentrated efforts, through various social media channels, to ensure tourists that Salmon Arm and the Shuswap region are 'forest fire free' and we are well-positioned to offer tourists an amazing vacation with memorable experiences."

Grayston says they are speaking with visitors who were intending to head into areas affected by fire about extending their stays - which has been well-received as an alternative to heading home early.

All 15 helicopter passengers and crew survived a close brush with death on Monday when their aircraft crash-landed in woods in the Russian Far East, a rare happy ending for a country prone to aviation disasters.
The Mi-8 helicopter, which carried forest firefighters and was conducting aerial reconnaissance, landed near the village of Chekunda in the Khabarovsk region, the Federal Forestry Agency said.
A senior emergencies ministry official, Vitaly Darchy, said the helicopter managed to land but "was damaged by a forest fire", forcing its passengers and crew to abandon the helicopter.
All of them escaped with "minor injuries," the foreign ministry said.
Officials had said earlier said the helicopter carried 14 people.
A spokeswoman for regional investigators, Oxana Polshakova, had earlier reported that the helicopter had crashed and burned, and that a team of investigators went to the site.
Deadly aviation disasters are common in Russia, often blamed on ageing aircraft and poor maintenance.
Aviation experts say the Soviet-era Mi-8 has an especially poor safety record.
On June 1, a Mi-8 helicopter carrying 18 people crashed into a lake in northern Russia, killing all but two of the passengers.

(BN) ((Salmon Arm-Evacuees))</p><p>The people moved out of Salmon Arm have been relocated to evacuation centres in Kamloops, Vernon and Kelowna.</p><p>Premier Glen Clark has assured them everything will be done to save their homes and property and praised them for co-operating in the evacuation.</p><p>He also promised financial aid if necessary.</p><p>Clark says this is the worst forest fire season in recent B-C memory. (CFJC,BN) ((Salmon Arm-Military))</p><p>An Edmonton military unit experienced in disasters is playing a support role in the battle against the Salmon Arm forest fire.</p><p>Charlie Company of the Princess Patricia Light Infantry helped in the Winnipeg floods and the Montreal ice storm.</p><p>Captain Brian Hynes says his 100 men are fighting a defensive battle against the flames. (BN) ((Kamloops Area Fires))</p><p>Three forest fires in the Kamloops region have grown.</p><p>The Greenstone Mountain blaze is now listed at 36-hundred hectares and two more water bombers have been brought in against the flames.</p><p>The Fountain Fire near Lillooet is now 17-hundred hectares and is being fought by 120 firefighters and soldiers.</p><p>The Elevator Mountain fire north of Kamloops is listed at 11-hundred hectares and is just 100 metres from the Yellowhead Highway, but the road remains open. (CFJC) ((Okanagan Fires))</p><p>In the Okanagan, officials are closing recreation areas because of the danger of fires.</p><p>Knox Mountain north of Kelowna has been closed after a weekend fire came close to a subdivision before being brought under control.</p><p>It's believed the fire was started by people, but officials aren't calling it arson yet.</p><p>Okanagan Mountain Provincial park north of Penticton has also been closed as a precaution against forest fires. A fire in and around the Primrose Lake air weapons range, 450 kilometres northwest of Saskatoon, burned out of control for nearly two months before it was brought under control earlier this week.</p><p>John Cook, provincial forest fire management spokesman, said the blaze - which burned 300,000 hectares, or an area half the size of Prince Edward Island - was officially listed as under control on Monday. "There are 380 firefighters still working on that fire - working on the hot spots as they move in from the perimeter,'' he said in a telephone interview from Prince Albert. "Most of the heavy equipment has been pulled off and it's being left to the long and hard work that's required to put out all the hot spots.'' Cook said between seven and 13 millimetres of rain fell on the area in late June, giving firefighters a badly needed break to control the blaze, burning near the Saskatchewan-Alberta boundary. Only 15 fires are still burning in the province, the lowest number since the forest fire season started in May. "Over northern Saskatchewan right now, due to the scattered showers and below normal temperatures, you would see very little fire,'' he said. Cook said all the fires are either under control or are being held. This has been a particularly bad year for forest fires in Saskatchewan, with 515 fires recorded so far, compared to 400 over the same period last year. Officials are still calculating how much forest was consumed by the fires.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5PVV-6BY1-JBVR-34T9-00000-00Scientist grades water risks from wildfires; prairies at top of list2017-11-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisWEATHER,NATIONALScientist grades water risks from wildfires; prairies at top of listScientist grades water risks from wildfiresBob WeberThe Canadian Press

EDMONTON - The Canadian prairies top a newly developed index of places where wildfires could create freshwater supply risks.

"We are a population depending on water coming from a fire-prone area," said Francois-Nicolas Robinne, a University of Alberta geographer whose research has just been published in the journal Science of the Total Environment.

Larger and more frequent wildfires are one of the more commonly anticipated effects of climate change, as warmer weather dries forests out.

Those fires have significant effects on freshwater. Burned-over areas can be prone to floods, mudslides and contamination.

All of those create problems for downstream users accustomed to reliable, predictable, relatively clean flows. They also have major impacts on plants and animals living in the watershed.

Robinne said his index is the first to try to assess those risks on a global scale.

"We have done forest fire hydrological research for 40 years, but it's at the scale of a hill slope," he said.

Robinne combed available information from around the world detailing everything from local soil types to precipitation and weather patterns. He looked at topography, lightning strike patterns, runoff, human settlement, forest age, vegetation, wealth, environmental and human water needs - a total of 33 different global databases, all crunched together and weighted.

"It's amazing what you have, but it takes some time to gather everything," Robinne said.

The result was a colour-shaded map that shows the relative risk that wildfires present to freshwater supplies around the world.

One of the areas at highest risk was the vast belt of forest and parkland that rims Canada's Great Plains and extends from Manitoba to Alberta.

"All the factors are here," he said.

The boreal forest is notoriously prone to wildfires, and in fact depends on them to remain healthy. There's also a lot of water in those forests that could be affected by a fire.

And all that water drains out from the mountains, heading east to dozens of cities and towns that depend on it.

Robinne is careful to point out his index assesses risk and doesn't make predictions.

"(Problems) may not happen," he said.

But the risks are real.

His paper points out that seven years after a 2002 fire, Denver had to spend $30 million to dredge sediment and ash from the city's reservoirs. In 2014, Sydney, Australia, had to shut a water treatment plant after heavy ash contamination.

Scientists and governments are just starting to address the risks, Robinne said. His work was partly funded by Natural Resources Canada and the Global Water Institute at the University of Saskatchewan.

As climate continues to change, planners have to start taking such risks into consideration, said Robinne.

"I'd like those big agencies that are involved in water management to stop and think about it."

(CP) - A feared cold front that was supposed to pack winds gusting to 85 kilometres an hour passed harmlessly over this half-evacuated southern B.C. city without pushing a nearby forest fire into town.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The front came later and proved weaker than forecast, forestalling a repeat of last Wednesday's conflagration that destroyed 16 homes and damaged 25 other buildings in Salmon Arm's rural outskirts.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- About 8,000 people, almost half the city's population, were ordered to flee the most threatened districts Sunday after B.C. Premier Glen Clark declared a state of emergency.</p><p nitf:lede="true">While evacuees went to friends, relatives or emergency shelters in neighboring communities, a force of 300 firefighters, backed by 100 soldiers, prepared to face the expected onslaught.</p><p>It never came.</p><p>The front moved through early Monday evening and the winds hardly rustled leaves.</p><p>Fire officials said the blaze was largely stable overnight.</p><p>The regional fire commissioner who recommended the initial state of emergency was meeting with other officials this morning to re-evaluate the evacuation and alert orders, said spokeswoman Anne Ferdinand.</p><p>"We hope we'll have a decision later today with respect to the evacuation and alert situation,'' she said.</p><p>However, the abandoned neighborhoods may not be ready for residents to return because gas and water mains in some areas may have been shut off to aid firefighters in their defence of the city.</p><p>"We're definitely not encouraging people who were evacuated to head home just now,'' Ferdinand said.</p><p>Crews using heavy machinery as well as shovels and axes have completed guards around the fire, removing potential fuel sources. They spent Monday dealing with flareups within the fire's perimeter, which expanded its area to 5,000 hectares.</p><p>A hectare is about the size of a football field.</p><p>Weather forecasters predict a high-pressure ridge will rebuild over the region for the next few days.</p><p>"That will bring hot, dry weather and winds will be fairly light,'' said Mitzi Bushell, a B.C. Forest Service fire information officer.</p><p>"We're cautiously optimistic at this point.''</p><p>Containing the fire within guards, however, is not the same as declaring it under control, Bushell stressed.</p><p>"It'll be weeks before it is under control,'' she said. "We definitely need some rain, some measureable amount of rain, before it can be considered under control.''</p><p>The evacuation made it easier for firefighters facing the blaze, knowing they would not have to contend with a crush of last-minute refugees if they had to fight the fire in town.</p><p>"It's a relief for me,'' city fire chief Ken Tebo said.</p><p>If the rest of the city was forced to evacuate, "to move them out in a very short time is just about impossible.''</p><p>Most residents in the affected area left between late Sunday and early Monday, leaving Salmon Arm a veritable ghost town.</p><p>Shops and restaurants were closed, leaving remaining tourists in the lakeside city with little to do.</p><p>But possibly hundreds of people chose to stay, at least until the danger was more imminent.</p><p>"If it was up to me, I wouldn't leave,'' said Bob Kline as he checked under the hood of his pickup truck. "The wife wants to leave. There is no wind right now, eh.''</p><p>Others planned to defy both the flames and police, who have the power to force them out if they impede firefighters.</p><p>Standing in the fire's way - an army of firefighters, backed by soldiers, a fleet of water-bombing helicopters and planes and dozens of pieces of heavy equipment, including 40 fire trucks from across British Columbia.</p><p>It was a baptism of fire for Charlie Company of the 3rd Battalion, Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry Regiment, who after a day of training helped deal with flareups and mopped up hot spots.</p><p>Some of the soldiers had fought fires before in Alberta and New Brunswick, while others were learning, said unit commander Maj. David Anderson.</p><p>He said his men, used to dangerous missions, were relishing the fire fight, but he didn't underestimate this enemy.</p><p>"Right now it's a series of small battles and I don't think there's been a major battle yet,'' said Anderson.</p><p>"I definitely think we're winning the war and we haven't lost a small battle yet when it comes to the fire.''</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier Right now, I'm looking at smoke about a quarter of a mile away."</p><p>Red Sucker Lake residents suffered a major forest fire in 1989 and Tuesday they sprang into action immediately on an evacuation and firefighting plan, Harper said.</p><p>About 80 residents whose health would be at risk from heavy smoke were scheduled to be airlifted to Thompson, he said.</p><p>Harper said the fire was definitely man made.</p><p>Provincial fire officials were bracing themselves for the return of hot, dry weather today, and warned that lightning from electrical storms could trigger new forest fires in northern Manitoba.</p><p>Meanwhile, more than 35 evacuees from the Northlands Dene Indian reserve were flown to Thompson Tuesday after what one resident called a "terrible, terrible" day and night.</p><p>Elders and young children were removed from the community 1,100 northwest of Winnipeg when it became shrouded by clouds of smoke from a forest fire five kilometres away.</p><p>Evacuees had to wait 12 hours inside their homes after the evacuation notice came because the smoke prevented the rescue plane from landing.</p><p>"It was steamy hot in there," said band constable Tom Soloman.</p><p>Northlands Dene patriarch Pat Hyslop said the fire had been burning in the area for the last two weeks and was getting closer and closer to the community.</p><p>Hyslop, who was chief of the band for 26 years, said the band council had asked for help from the Manitoba government firefighting branch but none came.</p><p>Fire control officer Ken Stewart said the community's request was considered but there aren't enough men and equipment available to move in there now.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5P1H-P391-JDH3-G2RG-00000-00Canadian Fire Fighter Museum needs to stay in Port Hope2017-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 1Canadian Fire Fighter Museum needs to stay in Port Hope

It seemed like the perfect opportunity. The Canadian Fire Fighter Museum, currently on Mill Street in Port Hope, needed a home, and the vacant Canadian Tire building looked like a good fit.

For the last 33 years, the Canadian Fire Fighter Museum has been in the former Port Hope Town Sheds at the south end of Mill Street. The museum must vacate the building as part of the low-level radioactive material cleanup. The Canadian Tire building, which has remained vacant for about 15 years, seemed like a good choice. With a large collection, including historic fire trucks, few buildings in the community would be able to house the museum.

However, after two years of planning, the Fire Fighter Museum announced they were unsuccessful in coming up with a deal to buy the property, which is disappointing.

The museum's collection has grown notably after the Ontario Fire College donated dozens of artifacts to the Port Hope museum. The museum covers all aspects of fire fighting history in Canada, including: forest fire fighting to structural to airport and all the gear and equipment in between.

Housing a proud legacy of fire fighting in Canada, it is hard to believe more people aren't stepping up to support the museum in Port Hope.

As a registered nonprofit charity run mainly by volunteers the museum's resources are limited.

Chair and volunteer Will Lambert said even as a full-season museum, it won't likely make money. Museums normally rely on donations and volunteer help.

It was a group of dedicated volunteers that raised about $50,000 to produce a feasibility study with designs and estimated price tags for renovations. The museum expected renovations to cost about $6.1 million or about $202 per square foot in the old Canadian Tire building.

Port Hope council did not support the museum's financial request to secure the Canadian Tire property citing a lack of a business plan. Talks with Canadian Tire then came to an end.

The loss of the museum would impact Port Hope.

Beyond the importance of safeguarding historical treasures, the value of such a museum is in bringing people into town. The museum is listed as No. 3 on TripAdvisor behind the Capitol Theatre and Shopping under 'Things to Do' in Port Hope and currently has five stars based on 25 reviews, that include headings such as, "interesting and should be better known".

Last year 4,700 people went through the museum in a six-month season. With a larger location and more on display the museum could draw many more visitors.

With other locations outside the community considered, we need to work to keep the museum in Port Hope. The museum needs help and now is the time to step up support.

urn:contentItem:5P13-TP71-JDH3-G31R-00000-00A fire can destroy many things - but not spirit2017-07-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisNEWSA fire can destroy many things - but not spiritAndrea DeMeer

The first person registered at the Princeton evacuee centre last Friday night was also the first person to lose her home to the out-of-control blaze.

Laila Bird, 81-years-old and a well-known local volunteer and personality, learned Tuesday morning that her home on Highway 5A had been severely damaged by the fire.

She was not informed through official channels, but saw a picture of her house on a neighbour's phone, showing a caved in roof.

RDOS has confirmed damage to two houses.

The colorful and vibrant president of the Princeton Hospital Auxiliary seemed equal parts shaken and resolute after receiving the news.

She agreed to an interview with The Spotlight on the condition that "no one feels sorry for me. I will take support and friendship, though..and please make the story funny."

Bird has been staying at a motel since she and her son William were hustled from their home Friday, shortly after the fire started.

She admitted to being a reluctant evacuee, and received several visits from Fortis BC and RCMP before packing up her dog, and her dog's belongings, and driving to town.

She finally fled when an RCMP officer parked in her driveway and indicated he wasn't leaving until she did.

"Well, when you are under attack, you want to attack back. I chose to do that with a sprinkler."

Well-known for her wisdom and sense of humor, Bird remarked: "It's very inconvenient to find a forest fire on your back steps. It's a damned nuisance."

(In a previous conversation with The Spotlight that was the same way she described having cancer.)

When asked to recall the possessions she grieved for most, she was at first stumped, then recollections came to her in starts.

The tomato plants and green peppers.

"Well, they're gone."

A pith helmet, a gift from many years ago.

"That might survive, pith helmets are quite strong you know."

She escaped with no clothes, and explained she had just hung the laundry out when she was served with the evacuation order.

"It's probably dry now, do you think?"

Personal photos and records are presumably lost, and she shrugged her shoulders.

She did regret, she admitted, forgetting to grab the batteries to her hearing aid.

"On the bright side, I am going to get a whole new wardrobe."

When asked what she needs most now she answered: "A teapot, and toe nail clippers. I had a really wonderful pair of toenail clippers."

Bird is unsure what she will do next, but she is relieved her home was insured, and she promised to rebuild.

"It is hard. It is stressful. But William and I are still here and the property is still there and Allison Creek is still running through it.

"People go through things. And they get over them. And we will too."

urn:contentItem:5RDB-HWC1-JDH3-G4JT-00000-00If 2017 weather was a downer, you ain't seen nothing yet: Environmental Defence2018-01-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisNEWSIf 2017 weather was a downer, you ain't seen nothing yet: Environmental Defence

When it comes to extreme weather, 2018 has a throwdown message for last year's show of hurricanes, forest fires and non-stop rainfall: hold my beer.

Predicting when and where extreme weather will hit can be difficult, if not downright impossible. But Tim Gray, executive director of Environmental Defence Canada, said Friday he has no doubt it will happen.

"I can say with certainty that we will have more wacky weather in 2018, and quite likely more than we did in 2017, as the world continues to warm," Gray said in an interview.

For those who might have already blocked 2017 from memory, here's a quick refresher: record heat and dry days in western Canada that fuelled B.C.'s most devastating forest fire season ever, while in Central Canada, it refused to stop raining and summer was missing in action.

twitter.com

The United States had one of its worst hurricane seasons ever, while parts of Europe suffered through deadly heat waves that led to forest fires and even the closing of summer ski hills in Italy and Austria for the first time in 90 years. Australia had the third-hottest year ever recorded in 2017.

The Swiss Reinsurance Company says insured losses from natural disasters in 2017 are expected to top US$130 billion, twice the US$58 billion average of the last 10 years.

Greenhouse gases like carbon and methane sit and gather in the earth's atmosphere, where they trap heat as energy - and energy drives climate, said Gray: the more energy in the atmosphere, the more extreme weather. And the amount of carbon in the atmosphere grows each year.

And while some tried to use the recent North American cold snap as evidence that global warming is a myth, it actually proves the opposite, he added.

Climate change doesn't mean backyard barbecues in February, said Gray. Rather, weather patterns of the past are being disrupted, with the influential jet stream breaking down and moving around more, leaving the climate more vulnerable to sudden shifts and extreme events in every direction.

Scientists from the World Weather Attribution - an international partnership of researchers from the University of Oxford, Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute, the University of Melbourne and the Red Cross Red Crescent Climate Centre - use historical records and climate modelling based on existing carbon levels in the atmosphere to look at weather events and whether they are linked to climate change.

The aptly named Lucifer heat wave, which hit parts of France, Italy and Croatia in August, was made 10 times more likely by climate change, the group concluded, and Australia's hot 2017 60 times more likely. The rainfall that followed Hurricane Harvey in Houston was three times more likely, their research suggests.

And the cold snap? Climate change has meant such spells are actually less frequent and warmer than they have been in the past.

That said, both Gray and the World Weather Attribution agree no one weather event can be directly attributed to climate change, because there have always been weather extremes. Climate change makes those extremes more frequent and the transition period from one extreme to another far faster, Gray said.

Mia Rabson, The Canadian Press

urn:contentItem:4KBM-HH50-TX4T-H1YT-00000-00B.C.'s Tumbler Ridge residents head home as fire threat lessens; 1,900 flee homes north of Saskatoon with more than 100 blazes being battled2006-07-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisFRONTPg. A4B.C.'s Tumbler Ridge residents head home as fire threat lessens; 1,900 flee homes north of Saskatoon with more than 100 blazes being battledCanadian PressTUMBLER RIDGE, B.C.

Residents of Tumbler Ridge displaced by a forest fire are being allowed to return to their homes after an evacuation order was lifted.

Chetwynd Mayor Evan Saugstad said yesterday the evacuation order has been downgraded to an alert, allowing them to go home but remaining on notice should the fire flare up again.

Tumbler Ridge residents in the Chetwynd recreation centre cheered and applauded his announcement.

Twenty-three-year resident Doreen Younge said the residents are used to dealing with adversity.

The town was built for coal mines that operated for several years before shutting down.

"Mine closures, contract negotiations, prices of coal dropping, housing sales, ghost town rumours. We've had it all,'' she said.

Six-year resident Ron McKenzie said he's happy his investment is secure.

"I bought a house when they were $29,900 and now they're $200,000 so I'm happy it's still here,'' he said.

The area had up to five millimetres of rain overnight.

"Because of the rainfall and number of days for the fire to rekindle itself and become a threat again and looking at the weather forecast, they can make substantial progress with a direct attack,'' Saugstad said.

"They're putting all their resources on the fire.''

Tumbler Ridge residents were evacuated Monday night because of a 91-square-kilometre forest fire eight kilometres north of town.

Forty people refused to leave their homes during the evacuation.

About 500 people were evacuated from the Anahim Lake and Tezla Lake areas in the Cariboo region because of forest fires.

Tumbler Ridge Mayor Mike Caisley said the fire going through the forest is devastating because the northeastern British Columbia community is known as a camping and destination resort for tourists and outdoor activities.

"It's tragic to see what's happening,'' Caisley said.

"We're not going to get that back in a lifetime.''

The town's 3,500 residents and about 500 people in the surrounding area were forced to leave late Monday night.

About 1,900 people have fled their homes northeast of Saskatoon because of forest fires.

The province of Saskatchewan was preparing to move 70 people from the northwestern community of Beauval because a fire was threatening the village.

There are more than 100 forest fires raging in northern Saskatchewan.

Saskatchewan Environment spokes-person Darryl Jessop said firefighters hope that rain forecast for later in the week will help stabilize the situation in the north.

About 150 residents of Nordegg, Alta., were ordered from their homes after a forest fire edged within three kilometres of the hamlet in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains.

Dozens of people in two area campgrounds were also forced out by the blaze.

Recent lightning strikes have pushed the number of fires in Alberta to 146, with 50 burning out of control, including the Nordegg blaze.

A B.C. Forest Service official said the growing number of new forest fires in the province is alarming.

Rhada Fisher says there have been more than 100 fires each day in the last 48 hours -- most caused by lightning and many of them small.

She said it shows how hot and dry the conditions are in B.C. forests.

So far this fire season, there have been more than 900 fires that have charred about 635 square kilometres of B.C. forest.

urn:contentItem:46YX-VM40-01G6-82V7-00000-00<published>2001-05-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:16:53Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NATIONAL GENERAL NEWS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BC-Alta-Forest-Fires, Urgent Bgt ; URGENT; EDS: ADDS highway closure para 11, RCMP comment paras 12-13, Bgt slug; INDEX: Environment, Health, Forestry; HL:Alberta town under evacuation alert in face of locomotive'' forest fire</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Bob Weber</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>EDMONTON</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>EDMONTON (CP) - Thousands of Albertans were under evacuation alert Monday as a wind-whipped forest fire charged "like a locomotive'' through dust-dry bush.</p><p nitf:lede="true">People in two east-side subdivisions of Slave Lake, Alta., about 150 kilometres north of Edmonton, were told to leave the area.</p><p nitf:lede="true">-BODY- About 7,000 other residents of Slave Lake were advised to pack their bags and be ready to head down the highway in the face of the largest of eight out-of-control forest fires in the province.</p><p nitf:lede="true">As late as Sunday afternoon, the so-called Chisholm fire was thought to be largely under control.</p><p>But under near-perfect conditions of dry fuel, the fire jumped the Athabasca River and more than doubled in size overnight. Winds gusting to 70 kilometres an hour pushed the fire like an arrow directly toward Slave Lake at the rate of six kilometres an hour.</p><p>By Monday afternoon, it was only 20 kilometres from town, leaving fire officials praying for a break in the weather.</p><p>"There are some things we can do to steer the fire,'' said fire behaviour officer Cordy Tymstra. "But when the fire is rolling like a locomotive, there is very little any fire supression agency can do.''</p><p>Slave Lake Mayor Gerry Allarie said the fire was already making its presence felt.</p><p>"It's very black here,'' he said. "There's lots of ash coming down on the town and the wind isn't doing us any favours.''</p><p>The municipality was responsible for making the decision to evacuate.</p><p>Highways 2 and 2A were closed for about 50 kilometres east of Slave Lake, said RCMP Cpl. Peter Quilty.</p><p>"They're anticipating the fire to jump Highway 2 somewhere in the Mitsou area (about 15 kilometres east of town),'' he said. "They can't give an exact location. That's why they closed the highway.</p><p>"It's like night-time here almost.''</p><p>The Chisholm fire has been aided by near-perfect conditions for a fire, said Tymstra. They include dry forests and strong winds that have turned the atmosphere above the fire into a giant chimney, intensifying its power further.</p><p>"The fire itself becomes a fire-driven engine. (It) overtakes the wind field and is behaving and moving unto itself.</p><p>"We've seen a number of conditions that were perfect for blow-up conditions.''</p><p>Even aspen and poplar trees, known as the "asbestos forest'' for their resistance to fire, have been exploding into flames in the onslaught.</p><p>"We're getting crowning action in aspen, which is unheard of,'' said fire information officer Rick Strickland.</p><p>Crowning refers to flames racing from treetop to treetop, causing the upper foliage and branches to burst ablaze. It usually only occurs in coniferous trees such as pine or spruce.</p><p>Relief was possibly in sight, however.</p><p>Weather forecasters predicted winds would shift Monday evening from the southeast to out of the northwest. That would blow the blaze back on itself and away from the town. There was also a chance of rain and cooler temperatures.</p><p>The Chisholm fire has already scorched almost 350 square kilometres - about 200 kilometres of that since Sunday.</p><p>Throughout the province, almost three dozen fires were burning with eight of them out of control.</p><p>About 1,600 firefighters from provinces and territories were either on fire lines or poised for them. urn:contentItem:5SJS-13P1-JDH3-G4TD-00000-00Correlieu Secondary students learn about careers in forestry2018-06-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisCOMMUNITYCorrelieu Secondary students learn about careers in forestry

Students from Correlieu Secondary School donned fluorescent vests and hard hats as they joined forestry professionals and summer students, forest firefighters, a biologist, an archaeologist and the B.C. Council of Forest Industries (COFI) for a hands-on introduction to careers in natural resource management on a Tuesday afternoon (June 5).

The event, hosted by COFI and West Fraser Mills in Quesnel, is part of a wider project to encourage local students to consider careers in the forest industry.

COFI expects 50 per cent of the skilled workforce in the forest industry will retire in the next 10 years. This means they'll have approximately 25,000 open positions to be filled across the province over the next decade.

Jim Costley is COFI's manager of forest education for Northern B.C. He says there are two reasons they host these events. One is to attract young people to the forest industry, while the second is to show them what it's really like to work in those jobs.

"Kids often don't know what goes on in the forest industry," says Costley. "We cut the tree, they see a logger, they see a truck come in and they see a mill make two-by-fours." But, he says, there's a lot more to the forest industry, and that's what he hopes to show the students who come out to these events.

Correlieu sent 30 students to the event held at Beavermouth Recreation Site off Quesnel Hydraulic Road, where they cycled through a series of workshops.

The workshops included timber cruising, where the students were able to practise using tools of forest measurement; archaeology, where the students walked through the forest looking for evidence of people who'd been there before and examined obsidian shards; fish management, where the students pulled on hip waders and went into the Quesnel River with a biologist to catch and release fish to practise classifying the river as "fish bearing"; forest fire fighting, where the students built fireguards and did controlled burns; and silviculture, where students practised using a drone, something silviculturists use to map out problem areas in plantations as well as monitor forest health. The students spent an hour at each station.

They gathered attentively around the workshop leaders, playing rock, paper, scissors to decide who would get to measure a tree or take the drone for a spin.

Sheryl MacFarlane, who teaches career prep at Correlieu, says it's her second year coming on the field trip. She says the students not only get to experience the day-to-day life of someone working in the forest industry, but they also learn what education is required to do that kind of work.

"I know students that are [working] in forestry because of this trip," says MacFarlane.

"They learned so much and they got excited about it, seeing, 'Hey, this is a career that I could get into.'"

MacFarlane's own son was one of those students. "This was the trip that changed his mind" about what he wanted to do, says MacFarlane. Now, her son works as a forester in Prince George.

For the most part, the students on the trip were there because they'd expressed past interest or curiosity in a career in the forest industry.

Braden Goyette, an Grade 11 student at Correlieu, says he came on the trip because he wants to be a conservation officer.

"This might be able to help me, like with the fishery [workshop], maybe give me an idea of what a conservation officer might do."

Goyette says he particularly enjoyed the fire fighting station. "And next year, I'm going to be doing their junior program, which is going to be awesome," adds Goyette.

urn:contentItem:5N2Y-F731-JDH3-G51C-00000-00'Leading alternative' picked for second hydro transmission line2016-11-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 01'Leading alternative' picked for second hydro transmission lineAlistair Waters

B.C. Hydro has zeroed in on what it calls the "leading alternative" as the route for a second transmission line to bring power to West Kelowna.

But of the three alternatives on the table, the chosen one is the one West Kelowna council likes the least.

In a letter to council, Sabrina Locicero, of B.C. Hydro's community engagement team dealing with the West Kelowna transmission project, says after 18 months of studying the three different routes, the one chosen for more study would see the line run from the Nicola substation in Merritt over the mountains to Westbank.

But earlier this year, when presented with the three routes under consideration, council voiced its concern about running a second line in the same general area as the existing transmission line.

Councillors and Mayor Doug Findlater all said a major forest fire in the area could take out both lines.

The two other routes under consideration included one to the Vernon substation along the west side of Okanagan Lake and another under Okanagan Lake to link into the FortisB.C. power system that serves Kelowna.

Locicero said in her letter the Nicola substation alternative was chosen for three reasons:

· It was assessed as more favourable from a overall safety, environmental,socio-economic and cost perspective compared with the Vernon substation alternative.

· It poses a low geotechnical risk, which can be reduced by routing and design and it's unlikely an event such as a landslide would affect both lines at the same time.

· With steel poles it would have the second lowest risk of damage from a wildfire. She said there is no record of a wildfire in B.C. being more than 20 kilometres wide and Hydro would build the new line in an area 50 kilometres wide.

She added the Nicola substation was build with redundancy and additional fire protections.

During the next phase of evaluations, Hydro plans to undertake more detailed environmental, socio-economic, archaeological, traditional use and engineering studies.

Locicero added some studies of the route under Okanagan Lake would also be done "in order to confirm our assessments."

There are no plans to further study the route up the west side of Okanagan Lake to the Vernon substation.

She said Hydro will continue to work with the Westbank First Nation and others and expects to make a final decision next year.

urn:contentItem:5P13-TP71-JDH3-G37P-00000-00A fire can destroy many things - but not spirit2017-07-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:16:53ZLexisNexisNEWSA fire can destroy many things - but not spirit

The first person registered at the Princeton evacuee centre last Friday night was also the first person to lose her home to the out-of-control blaze.

Laila Bird, 81-years-old and a well-known local volunteer and personality, learned Tuesday morning that her home on Highway 5A had been severely damaged by the fire.

She was not informed through official channels, but saw a picture of her house on a neighbour's phone, showing a caved in roof.

RDOS has confirmed damage to two houses.

The colorful and vibrant president of the Princeton Hospital Auxiliary seemed equal parts shaken and resolute after receiving the news.

She agreed to an interview with The Spotlight on the condition that "no one feels sorry for me. I will take support and friendship, though..and please make the story funny."

Bird has been staying at a motel since she and her son William were hustled from their home Friday, shortly after the fire started.

She admitted to being a reluctant evacuee, and received several visits from Fortis BC and RCMP before packing up her dog, and her dog's belongings, and driving to town.

She finally fled when an RCMP officer parked in her driveway and indicated he wasn't leaving until she did.

"Well, when you are under attack, you want to attack back. I chose to do that with a sprinkler."

Well-known for her wisdom and sense of humor, Bird remarked: "It's very inconvenient to find a forest fire on your back steps. It's a damned nuisance."

(In a previous conversation with The Spotlight that was the same way she described having cancer.)

When asked to recall the possessions she grieved for most, she was at first stumped, then recollections came to her in starts.

The tomato plants and green peppers.

"Well, they're gone."

A pith helmet, a gift from many years ago.

"That might survive, pith helmets are quite strong you know."

She escaped with no clothes, and explained she had just hung the laundry out when she was served with the evacuation order.

"It's probably dry now, do you think?"

Personal photos and records are presumably lost, and she shrugged her shoulders.

She did regret, she admitted, forgetting to grab the batteries to her hearing aid.

"On the bright side, I am going to get a whole new wardrobe."

When asked what she needs most now she answered: "A teapot, and toe nail clippers. I had a really wonderful pair of toenail clippers."

Bird is unsure what she will do next, but she is relieved her home was insured, and she promised to rebuild.

"It is hard. It is stressful. But William and I are still here and the property is still there and Allison Creek is still running through it.

"People go through things. And they get over them. And we will too."

Clearly, we have to deliver greater value when it comes to these services.''</p><p>While most of Saskatchewan's water bombers were built about 20 years ago, some have engines that are nearly 50 years old.</p><p>During the forest fire season, the province expands its fleet by hiring private aircraft.</p><p>Saskatchewan Environment, which regulates forest fighting activities, wants to replace six CL 215 aircraft with eight CL 415's, a $32-million water skimmer manufactured by Bombardier.</p><p>The government estimates refurbishing the fleet would cost $325 million, say CIC officials.</p><p>This year, the government spent $47 million more than it budgeted on fire suppression.</p><p>Saskatchewan Party MLA Brad Wall said such a public-private partnership may be worthwhile. But he's concerned about the possible involvement of CIC in a joint venture.</p><p>"Why isn't the environment department looking at this,'' Wall said.</p><p>"Why is the Crown Investments Corporation, who have their hands on far too much, involved? These guys don't have a great track record.''</p><p>Last week, CIC officials and Saskatchewan Environment representatives met with potential investors, including airplane manufacturer Bombardier.</p><p>The deadline for responses from potential partners is Friday.</p><p>According to a CIC document, the government is also willing to allow a public-private partnership handle radio services and support services, which include equipment and fuel, policy development and fire strategy, finance, human resources and administration.</p><p>The environment department would continue to oversee the work of fire crews and equipment on the ground.</p><p>If a joint venture or public-private partnership is to proceed, the project must meet guidelines set down by the provincial cabinet. That means, among other things, that the project must protect the public interest, achieve "value for money'' for taxpayers and ensure affected employees and communities are treated "equitably''. "We don't see this initiative as jeopardizing jobs in the north,'' Hansen said.</p><p>(Saskatoon StarPhoenix)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata The N-D-P is calling on the Harper Tories to provide more humanitarian assistance and work harder to investigate and prosecute alleged war crimes in Libya.

The call comes as M-Ps spend the day debating extending Canada's involvement in the NATO-led mission until the end of September.

Foreign Affairs Minister John Baird says Canada is increasing its humanitarian aid commitment by two million dollars.

And in a major policy shift, the government is going to formally recognize rebels fighting Moammar Gadhafi as the legitimate government of Libya. (12)

There are no reports of any major delays at airports across the country where Air Canada's customer service and sales agents are picketing.

The workers walked out overnight when the two sides could not reach agreement on pensions and wages.

Toronto singer Amy Sky was on her way to Nashville to record an album this morning and says she found staff very helpful when she arrived at Pearson Airport. (12)

The R-C-M-P, Quebec provincial police and native police forces are taking part in a major anti-drug operation in Mohawk communities around Montreal.

Police are executing 38 arrest warrants in an operation involving organized crime and drug-trafficking.

They say most of the drug seizures involve marijuana. (12)

About 450 northern Saskatchewan residents forced out by a forest fire are going home -- and they all have homes to return to.

Residents of Hall Lake and Sikichu (sic-KEY-chew) had to leave Sunday for La Ronge when lightning sparked a blaze less than five kilometres away.

It's the second time this spring forest fires have forced the mass evacuation of a northern Saskatchewan community.

(12)

Help is on the way for Americans confused by sun protection numbers and other claims on sunscreens.

The U-S government is ordering sunscreen makers to test their products' effectiveness against dangerous ultraviolet A rays that pose the greatest risk of skin cancer.

Under rules starting by next summer, they will also have to follow stricter guidelines when describing how well their products work against ultraviolet B rays that cause sunburns.

You'll want to look for the words ''broad spectrum'' on the label -- which shows a product that does an acceptable job blocking both types of damaging rays. (12)

A Pennsylvania appeal court has upheld the animal-cruelty conviction of an animal groomer who tried to sell ''gothic'' kittens with pierced ears and necks and bobbed tails.

Animal welfare workers seized three kittens and a cat from 36-year-old Holly Crawford's home in 2008.

She served six months of house arrest and was ordered to close her grooming shop for at least two years. (12)
